Award.AwardTitle: Syntheses, Anion Recognition and Self-assemblies of Cyanostilbene Receptors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The long term goal of this project is to address one of the grand challenges in the chemical sciences: How to design and perfect the atom- and energy-efficient synthesis of new forms of matter with tailored properties. To this end, Dr. Amar H. Flood at Indiana University seeks knowledge of how to design star-shaped molecules bearing holes in their centers to recognize and hold unique classes of negatively charged anions that were once considered too large to catch. By doing so, this research and these molecules can have impacts in removing toxic anions from contaminated water or manipulating anions important for human health. In addition, his research team investigates how star-shaped structures can be designed to self-assemble and fit together to form larger assemblies, e.g., nanometer-sized, soccer-ball shaped architectures. He aims to unfold the rules of their self-assembly because molecules cannot be picked and placed together like a lego set. Such materials could have impacts in compartmentalized chemical catalysis and for gated drug delivery. Broader impact activities of the project include training of graduate and undergraduate students, using 3D printing to teach principles of self-assembly, and developing strategies to increase the participation and visibility of under-represented minorities and women at conferences organized by Dr. Flood.

Under the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of NSF, Dr. Flood seeks to develop the syntheses of polycyanostilbene macrocycles called "cyanostars" for binding anions (e.g., biorelevant phosphates), and understand fundamentally how non-covalent interactions (such as CH H-bonding) and solvophobic effects influence anion binding. Furthermore, he explores the use of cyanostars in rotaxanes that can switch between states and in novel self-assembled architectures that stem from anion templation and 5-fold symmetry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

Pioneering work has been conducted on the creation of large cyclic compounds, called receptors, for the purposes of capturing negatively charged ions, called anions. This project has resulted in fundamental understanding on the idiosyncrasies and ways in which larger anions can be bound by synthetic receptors.

Along the way, discoveries have been made that break with conventional wisdom. Of note are changes to the way the community thinks about rigid and shape-persistent molecules. The cyclic cyanostilbene compounds studied in the course of this project, called cyanostars, were found to be both flexible and shape persistent. The shape persistence was likened to a hovering hummingbird: its wings are always in motion but its body (or shape) is unmoving.

A whole area of inquiry has been started that addresses molecular self-assembly, specifically involving the coming together of two or more anions. Such anion-anion assemblies were previously only studied in theory and have now been shown in practice. The anions bind to each other in unexpected ways because their discovery goes against Coulomb’s law. According to Charles de Coulomb, two anions should repel each other. In this project, however, anions are shown to bind to each other by hydrogen bonding. This all works because the short-range hydrogen bonds can be allowed to form and hold the anions together but only when the long-range repulsions present from Coulomb’s law are offset by placing the anions inside the cyanostars. Others have now started to explore this area of research and are finding the phenomenon is quite general.

By examining larger sized anions, it has been shown that the selective removal of such anions from solutions by cyanostar receptors does not just depend on how well the anions fit inside the cavity. Rather, it also depends on how stable the anions were in the solutions to begin with. While not a new idea per se it has led to unexpected selectivities that were seen before but not understood prior to this work.

The sum of all these activities is a deeper understanding of how to design receptors for larger anions and an appreciation for how their properties are different from smaller anions.

 

Broader Impacts

Over the course of the project, 3 postdoctoral scholars, 10 graduate and 4 undergraduate students were trained resulting in co-authorship on numerous papers, and multiple presentations at local, national, and international conferences. Two of the undergraduates have entered graduate school, three of the graduate students have continued as postdoctoral scholars, and two coworkers have recently become assistant professors. The PI has given numerous talks, including invited lectures at the premier meeting in the field, the International Symposium on Macrocyclic and Supramolecular Chemistry (Seoul, Korea 2016).

To broaden the participation of under-represented groups, the PI mentored an African American scientist leading to two papers. The PI Chaired and directed the “Integrated Chemical Systems” track at the annual Foundations of Nanoscience (FNANO) meeting to have gender equity: 30% of speakers were women (2014-2016) matching the 29% membership of the American Chemical Society. One postdoctoral woman coworker was mentored in the course of the project.

In addition to the multiple papers put out by the PI and his team, two two press releases on the project have been produced. These include an article published in Chemical Communications in 2016 on the patterning of cyanostars on graphite surfaces, which was featured on the NSF website. The Angewandte Chemie International Edition article on the anion-anion assemblies in 2016 collected wider journalistic interest. These included coverage in Chemical and Engineering News (the trade journal of the American Chemical Society), in Quartz (read by more than 18 million readers every month; 60% in the US and 40% in the rest of the world), in SpectroscopyNOW, and it was picked up on the NSF website.

The impact on society beyond science and technology for the project in the past year includes participation by the PI in an Art-Science collaboration and art show called (RE)Imagining Science. This work featured chemical?contamination in Okinawa, Japan. The PI highlighted how molecular receptors could be designed and made to capture?toxic chemicals, Agent Orange, TNT, and perchlorate. The show opened at the Indiana University Grunwald Gallery (Oct 14-Nov 16, 2016) and was showed at Philadelphia’s Esther Klein Gallery.

A US patent has recently been awarded on the composition of matter of cyanostar and its anion complexes is starting to have an impact on technology transfer. A small company has been formed to examine commercialization opportunities.
